Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Severe Tropical Cyclone Monica was the most intense tropical cyclone on record to impact Australia, with winds reaching 250 km/h (160 mph) 10-minute sustained and a minimum pressure of 916 hPa (27.05 inHg). The storm originated from an area of low pressure off the coast of Papua New Guinea on 16 April 2006 and intensified into a severe tropical cyclone before making landfall in Far North Queensland on 19 April 2006. After emerging into the Gulf of Carpentaria, Monica re-intensified into a Category 5 cyclone on 22 April 2006.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: No injuries were reported to have occurred during the storm's existence and losses were estimated to be A$6.6 million (US$5.1 million).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Linda was a tropical cyclone that developed into a hurricane in September 2015. The storm intensified into a Category 3 major hurricane on the Saffir–Simpson hurricane wind scale with maximum sustained winds of 125 mph (205 km/h) and a minimum barometric pressure of 950 mbar (28.05 inHg). Linda brought heavy rains to Mexico and the Southwestern United States, causing flooding and damage.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: One fatality in the state occurred from a drowning at San Bernardino National Forest. Utah was impacted by major flash flooding incidents—with rainfall amounting to 1-in-100 year levels—which left 21 deaths in the state: 14 near Hildale and 7 in Zion National Park.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: In Mexico, the storm brought rainfall to nine states, causing flooding, especially in Oaxaca, Sinaloa, and Zacatecas. In Oaxaca, mudslides resulted in the closure of multiple highways and damage to over a dozen homes. Flooding in Sinola affected approximately 1,000 homes with hundreds damaged, prompting dozens of families to evacuate. Several small communities were temporarily isolated after flood waters covered bridges. Localized flooding in Zacatecas damaged crops and 25 dwellings; damage reached approximately 500,000 pesos (US$30,000).

Two major incidents of flash flooding resulted in 21 deaths in Utah, the deadliest flash flood event in the state's history. In California, monsoonal moisture pulled north from Linda to produce thunderstorms across portions of California starting on September 8. One person drowned in the San Bernardino National Forest.
Two successive thunderstorms produced more than 2 in (51 mm) of rain near Hildale, Utah, in Washington County. Thirteen people were killed and three children were rescued.
A group of seven canyoneers entered Keyhole Canyon between 21:30 and 22:30 UTC (3:30 and 4:30 p.m. MDT). All seven people were swept away by the ensuing flood and died.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Damage across the Southwest amounted to US$3.6 million.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Carrie was the strongest tropical cyclone of the 1957 Atlantic hurricane season. The third named storm and second hurricane of the year, Carrie formed from an easterly tropical wave off the western coast of Africa on September 2. Moving to the west, the storm gradually intensified, reaching hurricane strength on September 5. Carrie intensified further, before reaching peak intensity on September 8 as a Category 4 hurricane with maximum sustained winds of 140 mph (220 km/h) in the open Atlantic Ocean.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: As an extratropical storm, Carrie impacted the Azores, though damages, if any, remain unknown. The extratropical remnants of Carrie later struck the British Isles on September 24 and 25, causing strong winds, waves, and severe flooding. Winds from the system were estimated at 50 mph (80 km/h). The strong waves caused extensive property damage and killed three.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: The extratropical remnants of Carrie later struck the British Isles on September 24 and 25, causing strong winds, waves, and severe flooding. Winds from the system were estimated at 50 mph (80 km/h). The strong waves caused extensive property damage and killed three.

Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Damage: Minimal damage was reported along Hurricane Carrie's path.
Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Effects of Carrie on Bermuda were minimal, with peak gusts reaching only 35 mph (56 km/h).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Cristobal was a tropical cyclone that formed on August 23, 2014, near the Caicos Islands from a long-tracked tropical wave. It gradually intensified into a Category 1 hurricane on August 26, 2014, and affected multiple landmasses from Puerto Rico to Iceland.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: At least two people in the country were swept away by rushing waters, [20][25], and many others sustained injuries.[26] In the Dominican Republic, two people were killed, one of them after attempting to drive across a flooded river in the Haiti Province.[1], and another person was killed by floodwaters in the Turks and Caicos.[1] In Maryland and New Jersey, two swimmers drowned in the rough surf generated by the hurricane.[33][35]

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: At least two people in the country were swept away by rushing waters,[20][25]
One person was killed in the Dominican Republic,[1]
One person was killed by floodwaters in the Turks and Caicos.[1]
Two swimmers drowned in the rough surf generated by the hurricane in Maryland and New Jersey.[33][35]

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The article does not provide a clear and definitive total economic loss or damage caused by Hurricane Cristobal. The text mentions that the storm caused widespread flooding and landslides in Puerto Rico, affecting 19 rivers and 7,000 people without clean drinking water. In the Dominican Republic, the storm damaged or destroyed over 800 dwellings and forced over 4,100 individuals to evacuate. In Haiti, at least two people were killed, and about 640 families were left temporarily homeless. In the Turks and Caicos, one person drowned in the floods. The storm also generated strong surf and dangerous rip currents along the U.S. East Coast, causing two deaths and leading to many lifeguard rescues. Later, the extratropical remnants of Cristobal buffeted Iceland with heavy rain and gusty winds, causing flooding around the capital city of Reykjavík.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Earl was a large, long-lived tropical storm that brought heavy rain to Puerto Rico and Newfoundland in September 2022. It originated from a tropical wave that moved off the coast of Africa on August 25 and developed into Tropical Storm Earl on September 3. Earl passed through parts of the Caribbean but was initially halted from intensifying due to strong wind shear. It then turned northward into a more favorable environment and started to intensify, reaching peak winds of 110 mph (175 km/h) before quickly becoming extratropical off the coast of Newfoundland on September 10.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Two people died after being struck by lightning in Puerto Rico, and two people drowned due to rip currents in New Jersey.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Two people died after being struck by lightning while riding a jet ski in Salinas, Puerto Rico.
Two people drowned off the coast of New Jersey due to rip currents.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Four fatalities were related to Hurricane Earl: two from lightning in Puerto Rico and two from rip currents in New Jersey. The storm struck Newfoundland with hurricane-force winds and significant rainfall, but overall damage from the storm was minor.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: A deadly storm (Klaus) blew in off the Atlantic and made its way across southern France and northern Spain on Saturday, causing widespread damage and leaving 20 people dead (at the latest count). Winds from the storm broke records for France with the strongest recorded gust hitting 184kph according to Meteo France.
Time_with_Annotation: Windstorm Klaus blew in off the Atlantic and made its way across southern France and northern Spain on Saturday, causing widespread damage and leaving 20 people dead (at the latest count).

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Winds from the storm broke records for France with the strongest recorded gust hitting 184kph according to Meteo France. No estimates for damage totals have been released by either the French or Spanish governments but it looks likely that this could top the 1999 winter storm Martin as windstorm Klaus has affected a wider area of land. At the latest count, 20 people have been reported dead.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Winds from the storm broke records for France with the strongest recorded gust hitting 184kph according to Meteo France. No estimates for damage totals have been released by either the French or Spanish governments but it looks likely that this could top the 1999 winter storm Martin as windstorm Klaus has affected a wider area of land. At the latest count, 20 people have been reported dead.

Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Damage: It looks likely that this could top the 1999 winter storm Martin as windstorm Klaus has affected a wider area of land. No estimates for damage totals have been released by either the French or Spanish governments, but it is expected that the industry loss will be significant. The estimate for insurance and reinsurance industry losses caused by windstorm Klaus has been increased by another 3% to EUR 1.675 billion.
Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: A deadly storm (Klaus) blew in off the Atlantic and made its way across southern France and northern Spain on Saturday, causing widespread damage and leaving 20 people dead. Winds from the storm broke records for France with the strongest recorded gust hitting 184kph according to Meteo France. No estimates for damage totals have been released by either the French or Spanish governments but it looks likely that this could top the 1999 winter storm Martin as windstorm Klaus has affected a wider area of land.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Floyd was a very powerful Cape Verde hurricane which struck the Bahamas and the East Coast of the United States. It was the sixth named storm, fourth hurricane, and third major hurricane in the 1999 Atlantic hurricane season. Floyd triggered the fourth largest evacuation in US history when 2.6 million coastal residents of five states were ordered from their homes as it approached. The hurricane formed off the coast of Africa and lasted from September 7 to 19, becoming extratropical after September 17, and peaked in strength as a very strong Category 4 hurricane.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: With a death toll of 85, Hurricane Floyd was the deadliest United States hurricane since Hurricane Agnes in 1972.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: In all, Hurricane Floyd caused 51 fatalities in North Carolina, much of them from freshwater flooding.
Four fatalities – two from fallen trees in Fairfax and Halifax County, one in a traffic accident in Hanover County, and a man in Accomack County who drowned in his submerged vehicle.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The Long Hollow Fire was a wildfire burning five miles south of Dufur, Oregon. The fire was first reported on July 26, 2018, and has burned 78,425 acres (317 km2). The fire was started by farm equipment.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The article does not provide any information on the total number of deaths associated with the Long Hollow Fire.

Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Damage: The article does not mention the total economic loss or damage caused by the Long Hollow Fire.
Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The article mentions that the fire has impacted recreational activities along the Deschutes River, and a segment of the river was closed for three days due to the fire's location in the river's canyon. However, it does not provide any information on the economic impact of this closure.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Mawar was a tropical storm that intensified into a Category 4 Super Typhoon before making landfall on Honshū as a Category 2 Typhoon. The storm formed as a tropical disturbance on August 18 and became Tropical Depression 11W on August 19. It intensified rapidly and reached its peak intensity with winds of 110 mph (175 km/h) and a minimum pressure of 930 hPa (mbar) on August 22. The storm made landfall on Honshū on August 25 and was downgraded to a Tropical Storm before entering the Pacific Ocean on August 26. The extratropical remnants of Mawar dissipated on August 30.

Time_with_Annotation.Start: A cluster of thunderstorms began to circulate into a tropical disturbance early on August 18.
Time_with_Annotation.End: The extratropical remnants of Mawar dissipated on August 30.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: Mawar made landfall on Honshū as a Category 2 Typhoon on August 25 at 1800 UTC (August 26 0300 JST) with winds of 95 mph (153 km/h).

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: One person was killed in relation to Mawar.[14]

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: One person was killed and seven were injured in relation to Mawar.[14]

Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Damage: One person was killed and seven were injured in relation to Typhoon Mawar (2005). The article does not provide information on the economic loss or damage caused by the typhoon.
Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: One person was killed and seven were injured in relation to Mawar.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The 2010–2011 China drought was a drought that impacted eight provinces in northern China, affecting most of wheat-producing regions and becoming the worst drought in the country in 60 years. The lack of precipitation caused lower than normal snow cover, putting wheat crops at risk of being killed by frost and reducing the amount of moisture in the ground.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Deaths: There is no explicit mention of the total number of deaths associated with '2010-2011 China Drought' in the article.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: By the start of June, the drought had affected 35 million people, including 4.2 million facing a drinking water shortage. Direct economic damage had reached 15 billion yuan (about 2.3 billion USD).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane How was a tropical storm that later became a hurricane. It formed in the Caribbean Sea on September 28, 1951, and made landfall near Punta Gorda, Florida with 70 mph (110 km/h) winds. After crossing Florida, it emerged into the Atlantic Ocean and quickly intensified to hurricane strength. It reached peak winds of 100 mph (160 km/h) on October 4 as it passed near the Outer Banks of North Carolina. The storm later became an extratropical storm on October 7 and dissipated in the far northern Atlantic.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Ultimately, 17 people died in the event.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Offshore, near Cape Hatteras, North Carolina
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: A ship called Southern Isle was wrecked by the high surf. It had been sailing from Puerto Rico with a full load of iron ore and, as it approached the hurricane, the vessel changed directions and slowed. By October 5, winds were strong and the seas were moderately rough. Very quickly, the ship broke into two, which prevented any time to escape on lifeboats. By the day after the wreck, rescue boats and helicopters found seven people, one of whom later died from their injuries.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Hurricane How caused about $2 million (USD) in damage. It was the only storm to strike the United States during the year, and consequently, 1951 had the least tropical cyclone damage in the United States since the 1939 season.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: European wind storm conditions continued this week with Franz/Gareth, as well as Gebhard and Heinz all current named depressions in the northern European region. Last week, actuaries Meyerthole Siems Kohlruss (MSK) estimated that wind storm Bennet (also known as Freya) had caused at least a EUR 200 million insurance and reinsurance market loss. Bennet affected mainly France, Germany and Switzerland on 4th March 2019.
Time_with_Annotation: Bennet was estimated to have caused around EUR 200 million of property loss in Germany alone by actuaries Meyerthole Siems Kohlruss (MSK). It’s important to note that this is the first estimate for Bennet, so there is the potential for the industry loss total to rise.

Draghi was the weaker of the two low pressure storm systems and struck on 9th March 2019, immediately followed by Eberhard on 10th March and affected a similar area across the British Isles, France, the Benelux states, Germany and Switzerland.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Deaths: The article does not provide information on the total number of deaths associated with 'Freya|Bennet'.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The McNally Fire was a massive wildfire in the Sequoia National Forest which burned 150,696 acres (609.8 km2) in July and August 2002, and the largest wildfire of the 2002 California wildfire season. The fire was started due to the 'careless use of fire' near the Roads End Resort in Kern Canyon.

Country_with_Annotation.Location: Sequoia National Forest, Tulare County, California
Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: The McNally Fire was a massive wildfire in the Sequoia National Forest which burned 150,696 acres (609.8 km2) in July and August 2002, and the largest wildfire of the 2002 California wildfire season.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The article does not provide information on the number of deaths associated with the McNally Fire.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: An extremely severe drought occurred in Queensland from 1991 to 1995, which was the worst on record. The drought was influenced by a strong El Niño weather pattern and high temperatures in July and August 1995, marking the fifth continuous year of drought in parts of Queensland. The affected region stretched in a 200 km to 300 km wide strip from Stanthorpe to Charters Towers. More than ten towns had lost irrigation systems, and some areas had gone five years without decent rainfall. A part of the upper Darling River system collapsed during this drought, and across the state, in more than 13,000 properties, totaling 40% of Queensland, was declared drought. The flow past Goondiwindi was the lowest since 1940, and cotton farms near Moree and Narrabri had been allocated no water for irrigation, resulting in a major loss of production. The town of Warwick was particularly affected.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation:
This drought was the worst on record in Queensland.
The drought affected region stretched in a 200 km to 300 km wide strip from Stanthorpe to Charters Towers.
More than 13,000 properties, totaling 40% of Queensland, were drought declared.
The flow past Goondiwindi was the lowest since 1940.
Cotton farms near Moree and Narrabri had been allocated no water for irrigation.
The town of Warwick was particularly affected.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Deaths: The article does not provide information on the total number of deaths associated with '1990s Queensland Drought'.

Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Damage: About half the usual wheat and barley crops survived in Queensland, leading to the importation of grains from other states. More than 13,000 properties, totaling 40% of Queensland, were declared drought-affected. The flow past Goondiwindi was the lowest since 1940, and cotton farms near Moree and Narrabri had no water for irrigation, resulting in significant production losses. The town of Warwick was particularly affected. No specific total damage amount is mentioned in the text.
Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The drought affected region stretched in a 200 km to 300 km wide strip from Stanthorpe to Charters Towers. Few wheat and barley crops survived, and grains had to be imported from other states. Across the state, in more than 13,000 properties, totaling 40% of Queensland, was drought declared. The flow past Goondiwindi was the lowest since 1940. Cotton farms near Moree and Narrabri had been allocated no water for irrigation, which resulted in a major loss of production. The town of Warwick was particularly affected.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: On April 22, 2020, an outbreak of discrete supercell thunderstorms led to multiple strong tornadoes, including a high-end EF2 that struck the town of Madill, Oklahoma, and an EF3 wedge tornado that moved through Onalaska, Texas. Two people were killed by the high-end EF2 tornado in Madill, and three more were killed by the EF3 tornado in Onalaska. Dozens of others were injured as well.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: On April 22, 2020, an outbreak of discrete supercell thunderstorms across portions of Oklahoma, Texas, and Louisiana led to widespread severe weather, including multiple strong tornadoes. Two people were killed by a high-end EF2 that struck the town of Madill, Oklahoma.
Two people were killed by a high-end EF2 that struck the town of Madill, Oklahoma, and three more were killed by an EF3 wedge tornado that moved through Onalaska, Texas.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Two people were killed by a high-end EF2 that struck the town of Madill, Oklahoma.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Two people were killed by a high-end EF2 that struck the town of Madill, Oklahoma.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Agnes was a tropical storm that developed on June 14, 1972, and caused significant damage in the United States, particularly in Pennsylvania. The storm made landfall near Panama City, Florida, on June 19, 1972, as a tropical storm and later became an extratropical cyclone on June 23, 1972. The storm caused extensive flooding, with the Susquehanna River and the Lackawanna River severely flooding the Wilkes-Barre/Scranton metropolitan area, causing major damage to buildings and infrastructure. In both Pennsylvania and New Jersey combined, about 43,594 structures were either destroyed or significantly damaged. The most significant effects, by far, occurred in Pennsylvania.
Time_with_Annotation:
Formed: June 14, 1972 (June 14, 1972)
Extratropical: June 23, 1972 (June 23, 1972)
Dissipated: July 6, 1972 (July 6, 1972)

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: In the United States, Agnes affected 15 states and the District of Columbia. Almost 110,000 houses were ruined by Agnes, 3,351 of which were destroyed. In addition, 5,211 mobile homes were either damaged or completely destroyed. Farm buildings and small businesses also suffered extensively, with 2,226 and 5,842 structures experiencing major losses or were destroyed. Of the 128 storm-related fatalities, 119 occurred in the United States.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: In Florida alone, 13 fatalities and $125.9 million in losses were reported.
In Virginia alone, 13 fatalities and $125.9 million in losses were reported.
In Maryland, damage totaled to $110 million and 19 fatalities were reported.

In Pennsylvania, heavy rainfall was reported, with much of the state experiencing more than 7 inches (180 mm) of precipitation. Furthermore, a large swath of rainfall exceeding 10 inches (250 mm) was reported in the central part of the state. Overall, more than 100,000 people were forced to leave their homes due to flooding. The Allegheny River reached above flood stage at several low-lying locations and at some places rose about 7 in (180 mm) per hour during the height of the storm. Additionally, the Susquehanna River threatened to reach record crests along its course. Some buildings were under 13 ft (4.0 m) of water in Harrisburg. At the Governor's Mansion, the first floor was submerged by flood waters. Hundreds were trapped in their homes in Wilkes-Barre due to the overflowing Susquehanna River. At the historic cemetery in Forty Fort, 2,000 caskets were washed away, leaving body parts on porches, roofs, and in basements. In Luzerne County alone, 25,000 homes and businesses were either damaged or destroyed. Losses in that county totaled to $1 billion.

In western Cuba, Agnes dropped heavy rainfall, peaking at 16.76 inches (426 mm) on Isla de la Juventud. At Cape San Antonio, the westernmost point in Cuba, precipitation reached 15.32 inches (389 mm). Due to high winds and flooding, at least 97 houses were destroyed and another 270 were damaged. In the Pinar del Río Province, the cities of Guane and Mantua were isolated by swollen rivers. It was also reported that extensive crop damage occurred in low-lying areas. Overall, seven fatalities occurred in Cuba.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Ignacio (2003) was a tropical storm that developed in the eastern Pacific Ocean on August 22, 2003. It reached peak winds of 105 mph (169 km/h) on August 24 and made landfall near La Paz, Baja California Sur, on August 25. The storm produced heavy rainfall across the southern portion of the Baja California Peninsula, causing flooding and damage estimated at $21.2 million.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Resort areas near the coast experienced minor effects, though further inland the damage was more severe. The impact of Ignacio was compounded by flooding from Hurricane Marty a month later, with damage from the two hurricanes totaling about $1 billion (2003 US). Four people were killed.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Two rescue workers died when they were swept away by the floodwaters. Statewide, four people were killed.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Severe Tropical Cyclone Magda was a relatively small tropical cyclone that brought minor damage to parts of Western Australia in January 2010. The system attained tropical cyclone status on 20 January and later reached severe tropical cyclone intensity on 21 January as it approached Western Australia. Magda made landfall in the Kimberley region with winds of 130 km/h (81 mph) before quickly weakening over land.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: "No fatalities were reported"

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Helene (2000) was a long-lived tropical cyclone that formed on September 15, 2000, and dissipated on September 25, 2000. It reached its peak intensity with winds of 70 mph (110 km/h) and a minimum pressure of 986 mbar (29.12 inHg). The storm caused direct and indirect fatalities, as well as damage estimated at $16 million (2000 USD). Areas affected included the Lesser Antilles, Puerto Rico, Hispaniola, Jamaica, Cuba, Isle of Youth, Eastern United States, Atlantic Canada.

Hurricane Elsa was a tropical storm that formed on June 30, 2021, in the Atlantic Ocean. It strengthened into a hurricane on July 2, 2021, with maximum sustained winds of 85 mph (140 km/h) and a minimum central pressure of 991 mbar (29.26 inHg). Elsa caused damage in several areas including the Lesser Antilles, Greater Antilles, Venezuela, Colombia, the East Coast of the United States, and Atlantic Canada.
Time_with_Annotation:
Formed: June 30, 2021
Extratropical: July 9, 2021
Dissipated: July 10, 2021

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: "There were 13 deaths associated with Elsa: nine in the Florida Straits, two in the Dominican Republic, one in Martinique, and one in the United States."[3]

"one in Martinique"[3]

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Danielle (2022) formed as a tropical depression in the central subtropical Atlantic on September 1. It strengthened into a hurricane around 24 hours later, but stalled and weakened due to upwelling of cooler waters. The storm regained hurricane strength on September 4 and reached its peak intensity with sustained winds of 85 mph (140 km/h) on September 5. Danielle then moved over a relatively cool part of the Gulf Stream and weakened to a low-end Category 1 hurricane. The hurricane briefly re-intensified on September 7 but resumed a weakening trend. Danielle weakened to a tropical storm on September 8 and transitioned into an extratropical cyclone later that day. The remnants of Danielle brought heavy rain to Portugal, causing flooding, landslides, and damage.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Deaths: There is no explicit mention of the total number of deaths associated with 'Hurricane Danielle (2022)' in the provided article.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Num_Death: One man was hospitalized after being swept away by floodwaters. At least four vehicles were dragged into the Zêzere River in Manteigas. 644 accidents were reported throughout the country, along with many instances of downed trees and flash floods. Portuguese authorities also reported minor wind and flood damage in Lisbon and Setúbal.
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: One man was hospitalized after he was swept away by floodwaters. In Manteigas, which had been ravaged by intense summer forest fires in nearby areas of the Serra da Estrela mountain range, floods and landslides caused major damage and at least four vehicles were dragged into the Zêzere River. Portuguese authorities also reported minor wind and flood damage in Lisbon and Setúbal. Between September 12–13, 644 accidents were reported throughout the country, along with many instances of downed trees and flash floods.

However, no specific economic damage amounts are mentioned.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Ampil was a tropical cyclone that caused moderate damage in the Ryukyu Islands and East and Northeast China in late July 2018. The system developed into a tropical depression on July 17 and strengthened into a severe tropical storm on July 19. It passed over Okinawa Island on July 20-21 and made landfall in Shanghai, China, on July 22. The system weakened over land and dissipated fully on July 26.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation:
About 1,000 people required emergency assistance.
A person in Shandong was killed by a fallen tree.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: A person in Shandong was killed by a fallen tree.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: From June to August 2022, persistent heatwaves affected parts of Europe, causing evacuations and a confirmed death toll of 24,501. However, upper estimates suggested more than 61,000 heat-related deaths between 30 May and 4 September. These heat waves were the deadliest meteorological events in 2022. The highest temperature recorded was 47.0°C (116.6°F) in Pinhão, Portugal, on 14 July.
Time_with_Annotation:
From June to August 2022, persistent heatwaves affected parts of Europe, causing evacuations and a confirmed death toll of 24,501. However, upper estimates suggested more than 61,000 heat-related deaths between 30 May and 4 September.

These heat waves were the deadliest meteorological events in 2022.

The highest temperature recorded was 47.0°C (116.6°F) in Pinhão, Portugal, on 14 July.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The 2020 East Africa floods were a natural disaster in Rwanda, Kenya, Somalia, Burundi, Ethiopia, Uganda, Democratic Republic of Congo, Djibouti and Tanzania, affecting at least 700,000 people. They began when excessive rains began falling in March, leading to massive flooding and landslides. They caused more than 430 deaths, notably in Kenya and Rwanda.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: Heavy rain, lighting and thunderstorms affected the country between 2 and 4 March, causing 5 fatalities, with floods reported in Kigali and Southern provinces. Two people died in flooding in Ruhango district, Southern Province and one person in Gasabo District, Kigali Province. One person also died as a result of lightning strikes in Rulindo district, Northern Province and another one in Nyanza District, Southern Province. A total of 13 people were injured and 42 houses destroyed. Roads and bridges were also damaged or destroyed. On 7 March 5 people died after heavy rain caused a river to overflow and flood a cave in Nyamagabe district in Southern Province.

237 people have died in flooding in Kenya in April and May while over 100,000 have been displaced. Flooding has affected 29 of the country's 47 counties. Wide areas of land are under water in Busia and Siaya counties, western Kenya, after the Nzoia river overflowed. More than 800,000 Kenyans in 161,000 households have been adversely affected by the effects of the ongoing heavy rains.

Heavy rain has affected wide areas of Somalia from 20 April, causing rivers to rise and flash flooding. On 27 April, massive flash flooding swept through the city of Gardo in the northeastern Bari region, part of the autonomous Puntland state. 16 people have died, 546,103 affected and 216,895 displaced. Hundreds of families have reportedly lost their homes.
1 person died and 280 were displaced after severe weather in Burundi during the period 2 to 8 March.

8 people have died in flash flooding in Djibouti. Djibouti city and surrounding areas were the worst affected after flash flooding struck on 21 April after overnight heavy rain. The UN in Djibouti said initial estimates indicate that some 18,000 households (approximately 110,000 persons) were affected across Djibouti city and its suburb of Balbala.

As many as 12 people are thought to have died in a landslide triggered by heavy rain in Ethiopia. The landslide struck in Ale Special Woreda in Southern Nations Nationalities and Peoples Region (SNNP). Six houses were completely destroyed and several families displaced. Seven bodies have been found, with 5 still missing. Search operations were continuing but has been hindered by unstable terrain. Eight people died in Gamo zone in a period 11 to 18 April. Flooding in Jinka town on 25 April damaged infrastructure and livestock. Other areas of the country have also seen heavy rain since late April. Flash floods on 24 April left at least 4 people dead in Dire Dawa. On 29 May landslide killed 10 people in Gamo Zone.

Thousands of people have been affected by flash flooding and landslides in Western and Northern Regions after heavy rainfall from around 1 May. Homes were destroyed and around 5,000 people displaced. Four people are thought to have died in the floods, with a further 3 people missing. Severe flooding and landslides occurred in Rubanda District, where 2 people have died and 31 houses have been destroyed. The landslides struck after hours of heavy rain on 2 May. Flooding in Kabale District in Western Uganda on 1 May damaged roads and homes. At least person reportedly died in the floods. About 500 families in Nakapiripirit district have been displaced and their crops destroyed following flood triggered by heavy rain on 2 May. Heavy rain over recent weeks has increased levels of Lake Victoria where more than 3,800 people on lake islands in Mayuge District, were told to evacuate as levels of the lake rose. On 21 May, 8 persons perished in new flash floods.
44 people died, 200 were injured, while 64,000 were homeless in flooding in South Kivu Province. Torrential rain fell in the city of Uvira and surrounding areas in South Kivu, from 16 to 17 April.

In April, thousands of people have been affected by flooding and mudslides in Arusha and Kilimanjaro, northern Tanzania. Two fatalities were reported in Arumeru District, Arusha Region, where at least 50 homes have been destroyed. Flooding has also blocked the important Arusha-Moshi road in Arumeru District, stranding hundreds of passengers. In Kilimanjaro region, more than 2,700 households in Moshi district have been made homeless by floods. Dozens of homes have been swept away by flash floods in Hai District.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Sepat was the eighth named tropical storm and the strongest tropical cyclone of the 2007 Pacific typhoon season. It affected the Philippines and made landfall in Taiwan and Fujian. Sepat underwent an explosive intensification on August 13, reaching peak intensity at Category 5-equivalent super typhoon intensity the following morning. The storm maintained its strength for 2 days, until it underwent an eyewall replacement cycle, just before he storm makes landfall in Taiwan on August 17 as a Category 3-equivalent typhoon.
Time_with_Annotation: Dissipated: August 24, 2007

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: At least three people drowned in the Philippines due to flooding brought on by heavy rains from the southwest monsoon enhanced by Sepat.

Sustained winds of 126 km/h (78 mph) were recorded off the Taiwanese coast as Sepat moved through the country. Heavy rainfall in Taiwan caused numerous mudslides, especially in mountain regions and in the south, resulting in an estimated $1.14 billion (2007 NT$, $34.5 million 2007 USD) in agricultural damage. More than 70,000 homes lost power, and nearly a week after the storm passed through, 9,000 people remained without electricity. The Suao-Hualien Highway was also closed due to landslides brought by the typhoon. One person was reported killed in Taiwan.

In Fujian Province, Sepat's winds felled billboards and ripped roofs off houses, killing two people. A tornado was reported in Zhejiang, killing 13 people and injuring at least 60 more. Most counties in China received almost 200 mm (7.9 in) of rainfall. Sepat caused landslides in Fujian, leaving 12 people missing. Landslides were the cause of at least half the 39 deaths in China. Damage was also reported in Jiangxi and Hunan, and damage in the four provinces was estimated at 5 billion yuan (US$658 million).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: European windstorm Victoria (Dennis) struck the British Isles and areas of north-western Europe between the 15th and 17th February 2020, coming just six days after windstorm Sabine (Ciara, Elsa) which caused a much larger loss. Impacts from storm Victoria / Dennis across the UK, Germany and Belgium drove the majority of the industry loss with wind gusts recorded at up to 100km/h. Victoria was a particularly long-tracked European windstorm. Victoria was originally identified on 11 February 2020 when it was still located over the US. Travelling across the mid-Atlantic in a north-easterly direction, it underwent a so-called ‘explosive cyclogenesis’ which included a rapid deepening of its central air pressure to 920mB, one of the lowest values measured over the North Atlantic since records began more than 150 years ago.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: European windstorm Christian, also known as St. Jude in the UK, Simone in Sweden, and Oktoberstormen in Denmark, was a powerful extratropical storm that affected western and northern Europe from 27th to 29th October 2013. It caused widespread damage across a number of countries, including the United Kingdom, Belgium, The Netherlands, Germany, Denmark, and Sweden. The storm was particularly severe in northern parts of The Netherlands and Germany, as well as in Denmark, where gust speeds reached over 190 km/h (119 mph) and storm surges reached as high as 7.5 metres. The loss and gust data relating to Christian, combined with the exposure data PERILS has gathered for the affected markets, serves to further increase the value of the PERILS industry exposure and loss database, enhancing the ability of users to improve their understanding of the risk of European windstorms.
Time_with_Annotation: It struck western and northern Europe from 27th to 29th October, causing widespread damage across a number of countries.
The storm was named Christian by the Free University of Berlin, but St. Jude in the UK, Simone in Sweden and Oktoberstormen in Denmark.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: It was one of the strongest storms of the last few years and reached peak wind gusts of more than 190 km/h (119mph) with storm surges reaching as high as 7.5 metres. Christian first impacted the south of Great Britain early on Monday, October 28, then moved along the English Channel and across Denmark and reached north-western Russia on Tuesday, though significantly weakened.
France, Belgium, the Netherlands, southern Scandinavia and the Baltic states were also impacted.
Gust speeds were particularly high in the northern parts of The Netherlands and Germany, as well as in Denmark.

It moved rapidly from the south of the United Kingdom in a north-easterly direction over the North Sea into Scandinavia. On its path, the storm caused significant losses in the United Kingdom, Belgium, The Netherlands, Germany, Denmark and Sweden.

The storm was the first of a series of strong and damaging windstorms to hit Europe during the winter season. In Denmark, southern Denmark recorded wind gusts of 194.4 km/h (121 mph), the strongest in the country’s history.

Europe has been hit by multiple European windstorms in recent weeks, not just Dirk and Xaver, showing that there has been no let up in the weather this winter. The latest, named windstorm Christina, has affected the UK and Ireland as well as northern France and some areas of Scandinavia in recent days.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Olive was a tropical storm that formed in the Pacific Ocean on July 29, 1971. It intensified into a typhoon on August 2, reaching peak winds of 155 km/h (95 mph) and a minimum pressure of 935 hPa (mbar). Olive made landfall on the Japanese island of Kyushu on August 5, causing widespread flooding and landslides. The storm also affected the Northern Mariana Islands, Ryukyu Islands, Korea, and Japan, resulting in 90 confirmed fatalities and unknown damages.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: 90 deaths were attributed from Olive, with the majority in Japan.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Various locations including Kasedashi City, Kagoshima, and Miyazaki Prefecture
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Heavy inundation damages were also seen throughout the southern part of Japan. In Kasedashi City, Kagoshima, torrential downpours broke the embankment of the Kaseda River, flooding houses and establishments near the area. The Kuma River in Kumamoto Prefecture also overflowed, destroying 209 houses and flooding 2,647 more. The dam in the prefecture, namely Ichifusa Dam, also released large amounts of water to avoid failure, flooding its lake and destroying some houses nearby. A rainfall amount of 59.8 inches in Ebino, Miyazaki Prefecture were recorded causing widespread landslides, which killed 69 individuals.
7 missing
Reports from different institutions and agencies, including Seoul's National Disaster Relief Center, said that Olive killed 27 in the country, all due to unknown reasons.

Four hotshot crews and airtankers were called in to fight the fire.
Crews dropped fire retardant on the south side, with the intention of keeping the fire from spreading towards Big Springs.
The fire jumped State Route 89A that day, moving northeast.
Highway 89A and Highway 67 were reopened on the morning of June 29, 2020 and evacuation orders were lifted for Jacob Lake and White Sage.
As of July 7, the fire has burned 71,450 acres (28,915 ha) and was 88 percent contained.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Kompasu (2021) was a very large and deadly tropical cyclone that affected the Philippines, Taiwan, and southeast China. The storm originated from an area of low pressure east of the Philippines on 6 October 2021 and was classified as a tropical depression by the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) and the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) the following day. The storm was initially disorganized but became dominant and was reclassified as a tropical storm by the JMA, who named it Kompasu. The storm made landfall in Cagayan, Philippines, on 11 October 2021, and later made landfall in Hainan, China. The cyclone dissipated on 14 October 2021 while located over Vietnam.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation.text: The Cerro Grande Fire was a prescribed forest fire in Los Alamos, New Mexico, that occurred in May of 2000. The fire started as a controlled burn, and became uncontrolled due to high winds and drought conditions. Over 400 families in the town of Los Alamos, New Mexico, lost their homes in the resulting 43,000-acre (170 km2) fire. Structures at Los Alamos National Laboratory were also destroyed or damaged, although without loss or destruction of any of the special nuclear material housed there. No loss of human life occurred. The US General Accounting Office estimated total damages at $1 billion.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Deaths: No loss of human life occurred.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Between 25–28 September 2019, Pune, India, and its division received heavy rainfall which caused flash flooding. More than 16 centimetres (6.3 in) of rain was measured in Pune, Baramati and Pune district between the night of 25 September and the afternoon of 26 September, leading to flash floods. The full Khadakwasla dam saw an additional 8.7 centimetres (3.4 in) of rain during this time, leading authorities to release some of the water to overflow into the Mutha River. Similarly, the Nazare Dam was also at capacity, and its waters were released to prevent damage. The flash flooding was caused by short intense periods of rainfall that overwhelmed water runoff systems like nullahs and flooded roads.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: "In addition to people lost to these floods, other rain-related incidents such as collapsed compound walls of buildings have killed at least 21 people."[3]

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: "More than 16 centimetres (6.3 in) of rain was measured in Pune, Baramati and Pune district between the night of 25 September and the afternoon of 26 September which was the highest rainfall in last 10 years. Coupled with the existing rain from the previous months, flash floods started to occur. In addition to people lost to these floods, other rain-related incidents such as collapsed compound walls of buildings have killed at least 21 people."[3]

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation:
Romania: At least 16 people were killed and large parts of several cities in the northeastern region of Bulgaria were submerged due to severe flash flooding caused by torrential rains on June 19, 2014.
Bulgaria: The worst-hit area was in Varna's low-lying district of Asparuhovo, where dozens of houses were swept away and streets were virtually unrecognizable due to piles of mangled cars and debris. At least 13 people were killed in Asparuhovo, with at least two others missing.
The floods were the result of intensive rain and hailstorms that had battered the country for several days prior, with some areas recording rainfall rates of up to 140-200 mm/h.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: At least 16 people were reported killed – 13 in the Asparuhovo district of Varna, one in Dobrich and two in the village of Tsani Ganchevo in Shumen Province.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: At least 11 people were initially confirmed killed in Asparuhovo, with at least two others missing. A further three casualties were reported from the city of Dobrich. On June 23, the body of a 3-year-old girl was found in the ruins of a house in Asparuhovo, raising the death toll in Varna to 12. A six-year-old boy remained missing and was presumed dead. Two people died in Shumen Province.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Varna Province, Dobrich Province, Veliko Tarnovo Province
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: At least 11 people were initially confirmed killed in Asparuhovo, with at least two others missing. Much of the area remained without electricity for more than 24 hours before official restored it in the afternoon of June 20. It was not immediately clear if most of the victims drowned inside houses or were swept away in their vehicles.

Wind gusts of 94 km/h caused significant damage in the summer resorts. Tens of kilometers of roads were flooded, disrupting traffic in the localities of Adamclisi, Abrud, Urluia and Zorile. Likewise, dozens of houses and 70 hectares of pasture were affected by floods. In Constanța, the sewage system couldn't cope with the large amount of rain, boulevards and streets being covered by water. In Mamaia, the rain destroyed a cafe on the seafront.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: This 'Quad-State' event has resulted in extensive damage, and sadly, loss of life. A long-tracked tornado is thought to have crossed all four of the states mentioned, with damage experienced across a significant footprint as a result. This would be the first quad-state tornado in history and some reports suggest the track may break records, running for more than 210 miles and as much as 4 hours on the ground.
Time_with_Annotation: As of 9:30 PM CT (Dec. 10), low-level rotation showed incredibly intense tornadic activity having tracked across parts of FOUR states — AR, MO, TN, KY. This 'Quad-State' event has resulted in extensive damage, and sadly, loss of life.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: This most significant loss of life has been reported in Mayfield, Kentucky, where terrible scenes of widespread destruction are emerging and local authorities suggest between 50 and 100 deaths will ultimately be reported.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Julia (2010) was the easternmost Category 4 hurricane recorded in the Atlantic basin since reliable satellite observations became available. It rapidly developed into an extratropical storm on September 20, 2010. The storm never posed any significant threat to land, and damage related to it was minimal. As it moved into a region of unfavorable conditions, it entered an extratropical transition.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Fatalities: None reported

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: As Julia never posed any significant threat to land, damage related to the storm was minimal. Trace amounts of rain reportedly fell across the Cape Verde islands, causing locally light flooding and minor inconveniences. Gusts battering the territory peaked at 30 mph (48 km/h), resulting in some wind damage to crops. In addition, these winds produced rough sea conditions, and high waves posed few threats along coastlines.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Phanfone, known in the Philippines as Typhoon Ursula, was a strong and deadly tropical cyclone which traversed the Philippines on Christmas Eve and Christmas Day in 2019. Phanfone intensified to typhoon status shortly before making its first landfall over the Eastern Visayas region on Christmas Eve. Further intensification ensued until Christmas Day despite Phanfone making several landfalls over the central Philippine islands, peaking at 150 km/h (93 mph) 10-minute sustained winds with a central pressure dropping to 970 hPa (29 inHg).

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The total fatalities of Typhoon Phanfone is 50 deaths (with 55 people missing, and over 300 injured).

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Iloilo, Eastern Samar, Tacloban, Roxas, Maasin, Boracay Airport, Batad in Iloilo Province, Leyte
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: The Visayas was the worst hit, with Iloilo City having 13 casualties alone that had been either struck by fallen trees, electrocuted or drowned. Roxas, Tacloban and Maasin all received 140 mm (5.5 in) of rain. The extent of damage in the Philippines was quite far, with the Boracay Airport being heavily damaged as many people were stranded in the airport as the typhoon struck. A disaster response officer also reported that power outages and damage in the town of Batad in Iloilo Province made it appear as a ‘ghost town’. Severe flooding caused devastating damage in the many provinces and islands of Visayas as rain spread across the region, with many houses and vehicles being partially to completely submerged. Most of the casualties are estimated to have taken place at Iloilo, as the village was badly hit with severe and swift-moving flash floods. Tacloban was hit as fires broke out and winds allowed them to spread but it the 220,000 inhabitants escaped the worst of the system. 147 cities were affected by power outages but by Friday, December 27, 31 of those 147 had their power restored.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The UK floods are now some of the worst on record in parts of the country. Impact Forecasting said that since December 2013, at least 5,800 homes have been flooded in England. Of that total, 1,135 have been flooded in the Thames Valley area alone since January 29th 2014. Rainfall levels in January were the highest since 1766, according to the UK Met Office, and February is so far trending well above the average rainfall amount expected. A number of severe flood warnings remain in place and there is expected to be more damage in areas around the Thames and Severn rivers over the next couple of days. Groundwater levels in some parts of the UK are now extremely high, meaning that further flooding can be expected with any additional rainfall.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: European windstorm Tini struck the UK and Ireland and brought additional impacts to parts of northern France and Scandinavia. Storm Ulla followed closely on Tini’s heels, impacting the same regions, of Ireland, the UK, some of coastal northern France and moving on towards Scandinavia.

The UK is in the grip of some of the most extensive flooding seen in many years, with parts of the southwest having been under water for over a month and flooding now affected areas closer to London where property density and overall values at risk are significantly higher.
Severe flooding has been experienced in Brittany.
European windstorm Tini and Ulla impacted some areas of Scandinavia.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Deaths: It is impossible to accurately forecast the losses from the UK floods with the situation ongoing and developing all the time. Further rainfall is forecast for the coming week which could increase the threat of additional flooding and cause further damages. The cost to the UK economy had been estimated at as much as £14 billion, from damage, lost business and general economic slowdown due to the severe flood events. In terms of economic damages, estimates now range from £1 billion to as much as £5 billion. Some of the latest estimates for the insured losses from the UK floods are for over £1 billion, with some suggesting that the final tally could approach flooding losses last seen in 2007 of £3 billion. An analyst from Barclays said that a £1 billion flood insured loss would result in as much as a 12% post-tax profit hit at insurer RSA, 9% at Aviva and as much as 11% at Hiscox. No direct mention of deaths in the article.

Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Damage: The cost to the UK economy had been estimated at as much as £14 billion, from damage, lost business and general economic slowdown due to the severe flood events.
Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The cost to the UK economy had been estimated at as much as £14 billion, from damage, lost business and general economic slowdown due to the severe flood events.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Xangsane (2000) was a tropical cyclone that made landfall in the Philippines and Taiwan. It was the 30th named storm and 12th typhoon of the 2000 Pacific typhoon season. Xangsane made landfall in southern Luzon in the Philippines, on October 27, and reached its peak intensity on October 29, with 10-minute sustained winds of 140 km/h (87 mph), 1-minute sustained winds of 165 km/h (103 mph), and a minimum barometric pressure of 960 hPa (28 inHg). The storm paralleled the eastern coast of Taiwan, causing impacts including strong winds and heavy rains, which resulted in 104 fatalities and $527 million in damages.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Xangsane was responsible for 187 casualties, including 83 possible indirect from the crash of Singapore Airlines Flight 006 on October 31, 2000.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Erika was a tropical cyclone that developed from a westward-moving tropical wave while east of the Lesser Antilles. The storm maintained a brisk westward trajectory, steered by a subtropical ridge to the north. Erika attained its peak intensity with maximum sustained winds of 50 mph (80 km/h) and a barometric pressure of 1,001 mbar (29.6 inHg) before passing near the northern tip of Guadeloupe and emerging over the eastern Caribbean Sea. The storm's remnants later made landfall along the southeastern coast of the Dominican Republic and eventually dissipated over Georgia.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: European windstorm Hendrik-Ignatz (Aurore) is the first of the winter 2021/2022 storm season to require industry loss reporting from specialist PERILS AG. The storm was named Hendrik and Ignatz by the Free University of Berlin, and Aurore by Meteo France. The windstorm formed on the back of an unusually strong jet stream for mid-October with wind speeds of up to 250 km/h, driving low-pressure system Hendrik and its marginal low Ignatz across the Irish Sea and as far as northern Russia within only a two-day period. Strong surface winds were experienced across France, Belgium, Luxembourg, Germany, Poland and the Czech Republic, causing widespread but short-duration travel and power disruption, and property damage dominated by non-structural losses to roofs, windows, chimneys and cladding, with more severe damage caused by trees falling on properties.
Time_with_Annotation: European windstorm Hendrik-Ignatz (Aurore) is the first of the winter 2021/2022 storm season to require industry loss reporting from specialist PERILS AG. The company has pegged its initial estimate for insurance and reinsurance market losses for the storm at EUR 311 million. The two low-pressure systems associated with the windstorm event were named ‘Hendrik’ and ‘Ignatz’ by the Free University of Berlin, and the storm was also named Aurore by Meteo France. The storm occurred between 20th and 21st October 2021.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Very Severe Cyclonic Storm Luban was the third tropical cyclone to affect the Arabian Peninsula during the 2018 North Indian Ocean cyclone season. Luban developed on October 6 in the central Arabian Sea and maintained a general west-northwestward trajectory. The storm made landfall on October 14 in eastern Yemen, as a cyclonic storm. Upon moving ashore, Cyclone Luban produced flooding rains in Somalia, Oman, and Yemen.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Jerry (2001) was a tropical storm that formed in the Atlantic Ocean in October 2001. The system strengthened into a tropical storm on October 7, reaching peak winds of around 50 mph (80 km/h). The storm passed just south of Barbados at its peak intensity before entering the eastern Caribbean Sea. Jerry continued to deteriorate due to moderate vertical wind shear and dissipated approximately 230 miles south of Puerto Rico.

No ships reported tropical storm-force winds, though Barbados reported a minimum pressure of 1007 mb.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Matthew was a tropical cyclone that made landfall in Central America during the 2010 Atlantic hurricane season.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: Matthew made landfall in Central America as a tropical storm, causing torrential rainfalls and local flooding in several parts of mainly Honduras, Belize and Guatemala. Minor wind damage has also been reported in some areas, and the passing of the storm has temporarily left several residents without power. At least 69 deaths have been confirmed throughout Central America; Nicaragua reported at least 66 fatalities, while three people were confirmed dead in El Salvador.

Matthew hit Honduras as a tropical storm on September 24, with maximum sustained winds of over 50 mph (80 km/h). Several power lines were toppled due to strong gusts; thousands of residents were left without power for hours, and forecasters warned that heavy rains threaten could cause flooding and mudslides in disaster-prone parts of several Central American nations. In Olanchito, near the northern coast, a creek overflowed and flooded a house, but firefighters were able to rescue its 10 occupants. Several homes and roads were damaged and made inaccessible, as well as at least nine bridges. Furthermore, there were no immediate reports of major damage; however, grain, banana, and sugarcane crops were severely damaged as rivers burst their banks. There were no initial reports of casualties, though 15 people were reported missing after boarding a sailboat off the coast of Honduras.

Retaining tropical depression status as it crossed the country, Matthew produced heavy rainfalls that hit Guatemala on September 25, causing scattered flooding across certain parts of the country. Authorities from Puerto Barrios—presumably the hardest-hit Guatemalan city—reported heavy flooding and several knocked-down trees caused by potent winds. The storm also produced significant flooding on sugar and coffee farms, which was believed to lead to serious sugar losses due to already-flooded cane fields from earlier rainfalls. Coffee trees also risked disease and fungus growth from too much moisture. All in all, Guatemalan sugar producers forecast that its harvest in November would be five percent lower than the 2.34 million metric tons produced in October 2009. There have been no reports of deaths or injuries as a result of Matthew in the country.

Heavy flooding across the country caused the collapse of several bridges and destroyed roads and communication lines, making it impossible to contact all affected communities. As assessments continued, concern awoke for the region's heavy agriculture production and the effects on livelihoods and economies. The storm and subsequent rainfalls have affected 255 communities, 80 municipalities in nine of the 16 provinces of the country, in the north, west and south. More than 1,000 families, some 6,200 people fled dangerous situations because of the rains in Nicaragua alone, seeking refuge in 72 active shelters. Throughout the country, 66 people were reported dead as a result of heavy rainfalls associated with Matthew.

As a tropical depression, Matthew moved into southern Mexico and dissipated, although the National Hurricane Center noted the potential for heavy rainfall accumulations of up to 30 in (760 mm) in isolated regions; the agency also noted for the possibility of 'life threatening flash floods and mud slides'. Throughout Mexico, at least 32 people have died due to several mudslides.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Matthew caused $171 million (2010 USD) in damage.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The 2008 South China floods began on 26 May 2008 and lasted for 20 days, affecting fifteen provinces in Eastern and Southern China. The first round of floods killed 93 people and the second round killed 55 people with 7 missing. China's National Meteorological Centre predicted heavy rain in the provinces of Guizhou, Sichuan and Yunnan, which would be 30 to 70% greater than in the same period last year. Mainland provinces affected include Anhui, Hunan, Jiangxi, Fujian and Guangdong. From 28 May to 2 June, some places in Guangdong experienced heavy rainfalls, killing 18 people and affecting 2.22 million people in 17 cities. On 15 June, more than 300 places in Shenzhen were submerged underwater, forcing more than 1.66 million people to evacuate and killing 63 people. The floods caused 67,000 houses to collapse. Officials in Guangdong warned of a 'black June' as high tides, rain and rivers threatened levees. Across the region, 169 were reported killed in the floods. The main precipitation areas included the Huai River valleys, Guizhou, Sichuan and the middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze River. At the end of the month, 252 people were killed in the rainstorms and flooding.

More than 240,000 power outages occurred in France, with most registered in the Brittany and Normandy regions. At the peak, Meteo France issued ‘Orange’ level weather alerts for at least 23 of the country’s 96 departments. Excessive rains prompted rivers to swell as hundreds of properties were inundated.
Nearly 90,000 customers lost electricity in Spanish Galicia due to high winds.
Additional damage was cited in Poland and parts of Scandinavia.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The 2021 Western North America heat wave was an extreme heat wave that affected much of Western North America from late June through mid-July 2021. The heat wave resulted in some of the highest temperatures ever recorded in the region, including the highest temperature ever measured in Canada at 49.6°C (121.3°F), as well as the highest temperatures in British Columbia, in the Northwest Territories, in the state of Washington as well as a tied record in Oregon.
Time_with_Annotation: On June 23, the United States National Weather Service warned of an approaching heat wave in the Pacific Northwest, whose origins could be traced to torrential rains in China. Six days later, Environment Canada issued a heat warning for Alberta, Saskatchewan, British Columbia, Manitoba, Yukon, and Northwest Territories.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The death toll exceeded 1,400 people, with at least 808 estimated in western Canada. The Chief Coroner of British Columbia reported that in the week from June 25 to July 1, 619 deaths were recorded due to heat exposure.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Between 13 and 18 May 2014, a low-pressure cyclone named Tamara and Yvette affected a large area of Southeastern and Central Europe, causing floods and landslides. Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina suffered the greatest damage, as the rain was the heaviest in 120 years of recorded weather measurements.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: 57 people died in Serbia, and the damage was estimated to be up to €3.5 billion. The heaviest flooding occurred in the watershed of the Sava river, which caused torrential floods and numerous landslides. The Kolubara river basin was particularly affected, where the major rainfall caused extreme torrents in the mountains. The flooded mines captured 200 million m3 of the flood water.

At least 24 people died in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the damage was estimated to exceed that of the Bosnian War. The Bosna river valley was hit hardest, and several cities, including Doboj, Maglaj, Zavidovići and Šamac, were completely flooded. The flooding also caused landslides and destroyed infrastructure, including bridges and roads.

Croatia was affected to a lesser extent than Serbia or Bosnia, but the embankment on the Sava River was breached near Rajevo Selo and Račinovci, and around 15,000 people were evacuated from their homes. The most critical point was the embankment of the Sava river in Slavonski Šamac, where the confluence of the Bosna and Sava is located. Several officials stated that if this embankment were breached, the entire region of southern Slavonia would be flooded.

Romania was affected by three major floods since late April 2014, and over 8,000 people were isolated and nearly 2,000 hectares of land were covered by water. The waters of the Danube rose so much that the authorities set orange code for flooding for eight days, on the sector Iron Gates–Zimnicea. Bucharest was also devastated by a storm accompanied by hail and strong winds, and several streets were flooded and trees were uprooted.
Floods and strong winds from the cyclone also reached Slovakia, where an elderly man drowned.
